story.
On May 13th, 2021, a minor chlorine leak resulted in an injury (OSHA recordable) to a Corteva employee. Approximately three pounds of chlorine was released as the result of packing failure on one of the valves.  The injured employee was looking for the leak without wearing the appropriate PPE.  As a result of the incident, Operations was retrained on PPE requirements and new equipment was purchased to facilitate the identification of leak points. There were no offsite consequences.

5. Emergency Response Plan
Pittsburg Operations utilizes a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, sheltering-in-place, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, Pittsburg Operations emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place that would require a modified emergency response.

CA Region II LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the emergency plan for the Pittsburg Operations site has been coordinated and verified. Pittsburg Operations also coordinates our plans and actions with local agencies and industrial mutual aid groups, which provide Pittsburg Operations with additional emergency response capability.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Improving safety is a continuous process at Pittsburg Operations.  PHA's, Compliance Audits, Technology Reviews, Facility Self-Assessments and Management System Reviews, Incident Investigations, Emergency Response Drills and employee participation are a primary means for identifying opportunities to improve safety.  Structural seismic upgrades, materials of construction upgrades, installation of additional process instrumentation and/or proces

timely and appropriate manner.

Incident Investigation
Pittsburg Operations promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Pittsburg Operations truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  Element-specific employee surveys or management system reviews are conducted quarterly, and the results are summarized and shared with all site personnel. In addition, Pittsburg Operations employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is required for each of the jobs at the site.

Contractors
Pittsburg Operations hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction, and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Pittsburg Operations has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform Pittsburg Operations of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

4. Five-year Accident History
Pittsburg Operations has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases due to the site's release prevention policies.  There is only one accident on the sites five-year accident hi

rocesses are competent in the operating procedures and safe work practices associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years, and more frequently as needed, for required process and safety topics.

Mechanical Integrity
Pittsburg Operations carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance.  These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Pittsburg Operations to safely manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at Pittsburg Operations.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Pittsburg Operations conducts self assessments of the management systems designed to ensure RMP requirements on a regular basis.  These self assessments are carried out at least once every 3 years by each facility.  Any corrective actions identified as a result of the self assessments are tracked to ensure resolution in a

ned and constructed in accordance with RAGAGEP.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.

Process Safety Information
Pittsburg Operations maintains detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include: Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams, equipment specification sheets, reactive chemicals testing reports, and corrosion reports.  This information is regularly reviewed, as needed, and is readily accessible to plant operations personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis
Pittsburg Operations conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and effectively controlled.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis (RC/PHA), Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Reactive Chemical Reviews, and Project Safety & Loss Prevention Reviews.  Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a regular basis.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within Pittsburg Operations' covered processes, written operating procedures are maintained.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  This information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to plant operations personnel.

Training
Pittsburg Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating p

ations comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at Pittsburg Operations.  It is Pittsburg Operations' policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Pittsburg Operations is also committed to responding to emergencies resulting from accidental releases in order to mitigate the release and any associated consequences.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activity at Pittsburg Operations is agricultural chemical manufacturing.  Pittsburg Operations has four regulated substances present at the site in quantities above the Federal RMP threshold quantities.  These substances are chlorine, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), hydrogen fluoride (anhydrous) and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous).  Chlorine is used in making of intermediate and finished products for agricultural applications and is a byproduct of these processes.  Hydrogen chloride (anhydrous) is made as a co-product of some of the agricultural product manufacturing processes.  The site manages sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) railcars and hydrogen fluoride railcars for a site tenant that uses those chemicals to manufacture an agricultural product. 
Note:  Ammonia (anhydrous) is used in pollution control equipment for a boiler at Pittsburg Operations.  Inventory of ammonia (anhydrous) is below the Federal RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.  However, the inventory is above the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program threshold quantity of 500 lbs.  Therefore, the unit operation using ammonia (anhydrous) is regulated under the CalARP Program.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program
Pittsburg Operations has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  Pittsburg Operations was desig

ntory of Hydrogen chloride (anhydrous) [Hydrochloric acid] below the Federal threshold quantity continues to be reported under this process to represent a unit operation that is considered a covered process due to connection to an anhydrous hydrogen chloride supply header (per the interconnectivity rule).

e) 660 Block Operations, Process ID 1000130907:
As mentioned in item b., a unit operation formerly in 560 Block Operations, Process ID 1000130905, has been moved into 660 Block Operations, Process ID 1000130907 due to connection to the chlorine header.  In addition, a thermal oxidizing (TOX) unit has been added to this covered process.  The TOX unit operation does not contribute to inventory of regulated flammable or toxic chemicals in the process but is covered based on potential fire or explosion impact on nearby chlorine piping.

f) WCS / ARS
Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for all remaining unit operations and regulated chemicals were re-evaluated to be current as part of the update.  Where possible, RMP*Comp was used more extensively for calculating release rates in place of other local data sources.  Estimated residential populations within distance to endpoint were calculated in the most current version of MARPLOT (Version 5.1.1) and updated as needed.
Toxic Alter ID: 1000112091 for aqueous ammonia in the 640 Block Operations process was removed due to the removal of that process from the resubmission.  (See item c. above)
Toxic Alter ID: 1000112087 for hydrogen fluoride in the 310 Block Operations process was removed due to the removal of that process from the resubmission.  (See item a. above.)  This ARS was replaced with a new scenario for HF release from railcar for the Site Logistics process, Process ID 1000130930.

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Pittsburg Oper

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations

Revision History:
March 2024  This resubmission is a 5-year update for Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations.  The 5-year update, which is due July 12, 2024, includes general updates as well as significant changes related to the shutdown of several manufacturing unit operations onsite in late 2023 and early 2024.

a) 310 Block Operations  Process ID 1000130906:
This process has been removed completely from the current resubmission.  The two unit operations previously defined in this process handled hydrogen fluoride (HF).  These units have permanently ceased operation.  Inventories within the process equipment are below threshold quantities for HF, and process equipment has been isolated from potential HF sources.  

b) 560 Block Operations  Process ID 1000130905:
This process has been removed completely from the current resubmission.  The two unit operations previously defined in this process handled chlorine.  One unit has permanently ceased operation with inventories below threshold quantities for chlorine and isolation from potential chlorine sources.  The second unit operation continues to be considered a covered process due to connection to the 660 Block Operations chlorine supply header (per the interconnectivity rule) and has been added into the process boundaries of the 660 Block Operations, Process ID 1000130907.

c) 640 Block Operations  Process ID 1000130908:
This process has been removed completely from the current resubmission.  The unit operation previously defined in this process handled aqueous ammonia (concentration greater than 20%).  The unit has permanently ceased operation with inventories below threshold quantities for aqueous ammonia and isolation from potential sources of aqueous ammonia.  As a result of this change, aqueous ammonia has been removed from the sites list of regulated chemicals.

d) 520 Block Operations, Process ID 1000130929:
